awd_titl_txt: RUI: Nuclear Physics at Hope College With Undergraduates: New Science Enhancing the STEM Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
The abundance of the elements in the universe, especially those with atomic number greater than iron, depend on the nuclear properties of a wide variety of neutron-rich nuclei, many of which are formed in supernovas and neutron star mergers. The properties of these nuclei are determined by the strong and weak nuclear forces and the PI and his students will explore the specific subtleties of the nuclear force by studying the structure of neutron-rich nuclei near the neutron dripline.  In addition, nuclear physics techniques and technology will be combined with the Hope College accelerator to characterize a wide variety of samples ranging from electrodeposited films to superconductors to environmental samples.  Undergraduate researchers will play a central role in  all of these efforts.

Along with other researchers in the MoNA Collaboration, a measurement of the energy of the lowest spin and parity level (1/2 minus) in Be-13 has been approved and will be made with the spectrometer in 2020.  As soon as possible, Hope College researchers will participate in a second collaboration experiment with a focus on F-28.  Both of these experiments will require moving MoNA into a new vault at the National Superconducting Cyclotron Laboratory.  Hope researchers will continue to analyze the beta decay of Ni-61, Ni-63 and Rb-71, which are of astrophysical interest. The Summing NaI (SuN) detector has been equipped with a moving tape target surrounded by a beta detector fabricated at Hope College.  Hope researchers will participate in several approved experiments at the NSCL and Argonne with special emphasis on those requiring the SuN detector (including studies of Sm, Br, I, Sn, and others).  Lastly, the local Hope accelerator will be used to apply particle-induced gamma-ray emission, particle-induced x-ray emission, and Rutherford backscattering spectroscopy to characterize a range of samples in partnership with other research groups from Hope and outside.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Hope College Nuclear Group is active in three nuclear physics research directions.  The Group has partnered with two large R1 collaborations in order to increase our scientific impact: the Modular Neutron Array collaboration (MoNA) and the Summing NaI (SuN) group.  Both research groups are based at the Facility for Rare Isotope Beams (FRIB) at Michigan State University.  Actual experiments are conducted at FRIB and Argonne National Laboratories (ANL).

The physics investigated by the MoNA Collaboration (FRIB researchers combined with faculty and students from nine undergraduate institutions) centers on the nuclear structure of unstable neutron-rich nuclei far from stability.  Measurements of the energy levels in these unstable nuclei, which quickly decay by emitting one or more neutrons, provides experimental data that allow theorists to refine the current models of the nuclear force.  The PI was the principal spokesperson for one of the last experiments to be conducted at the coupled cyclotron facility before the shutdown for conversion to FRIB.  This experiment was designed to settle ongoing questions about the placement of excited levels in 13Be.  Following that the Nuclear Group has been active in supervising the analysis of this experiment, planning for approved experiments with FRIB in 2024, and designing the next-generation neutron detector to be used by MoNA with the high-spectrometer at FRIB.  The Nuclear Group is also instrumental in the collaboration as the experts in the design and implementation of the neutron detector trigger logic.

The physics investigated by the SuN group centers on nuclei and reactions that are part of the various processes that form the heavy elements observed in the universe.  The heavy nuclei are formed in a variety of astrophysical events (e.g. star mergers or supernovae) in a large chain of reactions (e.g. rapid neutron process).  In particular, Nuclear Group researchers are very experienced in extracting the specifics of how individual nuclei beta decay to specific excited child levels.    The reactions and nuclei are produced and studied at both FRIB and the CARIBU facility at ANL.  The determination of the beta decay intensity function is well suited to undergraduates and the Nuclear Group has a steady rate of papers and expects the production to continue.  The Nuclear Group is also highly valued by the SuN group because of our expertise in fabrications.  The Group is responsible for the moving tape control system, the plastic beta detector that accompanies the tape system, the large plastic cosmic-ray veto detector system, and the design of the gas cell targets.

The Nuclear Group also has responsibility for the local accelerator (a 1.7 MV tandem with Alphtross ion source).  During this award, a significant effort was expended to adapt a nuclear technique (particle-induced gamma-ray emission) to the detection of PFAS (a carcinogen) in groundwater.  There are distinctive gamma rays from the inelastic excitation of 19F that can be detected with a Ge detector.  This effort includes the development of a reproducible, non-chemical concentration technique and the development of a low-cost Compton scattering suppressor; both aimed at lowering the level of detection as low as possible.  The Nuclear group also partners with other researchers making use of the accelerator.  For example, the Group has partnered with Indiana University researchers to measure oxygen in Si targets and works with an engineer at Hope to develop photovoltaic materials that are robust again radiation damage.  Lastly, the local accelerator is central to a research-like experience for first-year students.  They learn the operation of the device and other research skills, and their pride and experience improves retention in the physics program.

The physics results from our efforts have resulted in 10 publications (all peer reviewed).  Of note is that four of these have an undergraduate researcher as the first author.

Another part of the Nuclear Group?s mission is to enhance the nation?s STEM workforce.  Participation in work supported by this award educates and enthuses undergraduate students to pursue careers in STEM fields.  Most of the students, nine associated with this award, continue on to advanced study.  Starting in August of 2021, the group was joined by an FRIB postdoctoral research, and the PI is serving as a mentor with the goal being that this person will ultimately be part of the next generation of educators training undergraduate physicists.
